item.title: Scientist, engineer, or entrepreneur? Draft
item.dc:creator: hjunye
item.content:encoded:
Scientist, engineer, or entrepreneur?
This question has struck me many times in my life.
Two years ago, I found my notebook in primary school when I cleared my stuff of my room in my hometown. In the notebook, it was written "I want to become a scientist who devote himself to contributing to humanity." It was a surprise and joy to found this sentence, although it was merely a dream from a 10-year-old boy who didn't have a single idea what it took to become a scientist.
In high school, I was amazed by Google's products (especially Google Earth) and its mission statement: "to organise the world’s information and make it universally accessible and useful". At that time Microsoft was still the biggest IT company, but Google was growing very rapidly and everyone expects it to beat Microsoft to become the Kind of IT. Very naturally, my dream was to build a company which will beat Google and become the King of IT. It was merely a joke: I said it just because it sounded cool to do so.
I stated to think about this question more seriously in university.
I chose Materials Engineering as my major in China because my high school chemistry teacher once said: materials is the future of 21st century. That wasn't the only reason though. I loved both physics and chemistry. However, I never thought that I could become a physicist or a chemist; they are too tough for me. And if I can't become a scientist (do PhD), the outcome could be devastating if I chose physics or chemistry major: immediate unemployment after graduation. So I thought materials engineering might be a good choice: I have the possibility of becoming a scientist, and the possibility of working in a company after undergraduate.
Before I got to know more about materials engineering program in my Chinese university, I was chosen to study in Nanyang Technological University in Singapore under a scholarship. I had one more chance to change my major. During the bridging course (6-month preparatory course before entering NTU), I was crazy about programming. For a while, I couldn't sleep very well. My mind was full of codes and algorithms. I could wake up in the midnight with a new idea from my subconscious in the dream and start coding. Eventually, I put Computer Science and Computer Engineering under Materials Engineering as my major choices. Of course, because materials engineering was not a very popular major, I was enrolled in the major instead of computer.
So again, I studied materials engineering. I started to do research as early as my second year. At that time I was fascinated by additive manufacturing, or more commonly known, 3D printing. I started my first research attachment in Singapore Institute of Manufacturing Technology (SIMTech). Later in my third year's internship, I went to a local 3D printer manufacturing startup called Pirate3D. Compared to Pirate3D (same field but different style) and the research I have done later (same style but different field), my research project in SIMTech was primitive and of low productivity, despite that I had a great Iranian mentor who always gave me a lot of encouragement and inspirations. While I was an exchange student in Tokyo Institute of Technology, I did some research on nanogap electrodes.
(blahblahblah about my history)
Scientist - Einstein, CN Yang
Engineer - Nikola Tesla
Entrepreneur - Steve Jobs

item.title: Random Walk to Physics
item.dc:creator: hjunye
item.content:encoded: This is the second post in the blog. I think I should probably give a brief introduction of myself. I was born and raised in Qingyuan, a small city in the Guangdong Province in South China. After a brief staying (really brief, only 3 months) in South China University of Technology (SCUT), I was awarded a scholarship to study in Nanyang Technological University (NTU), Singapore. In SCUT, my major was materials science and engineering (MSE). I can't remember what really made me choose this particular major, but I was convinced by myself that the reason was because my favourite chemistry teacher once said in the class: materials is the future! I didn't understand really what MSE is. But I thought it sounds like an interesting combination of chemistry and physics, which are both my favourite subjects (and both I did pretty well in school too). When I got the scholarship to study in NTU, I had one chance to change my major. At that time I really loved programming, so I wanted to change to computer science. But I still loved chemistry and physics, so I put "materials engineering (the acronym should be ME, but usually ME refers to mechanical engineering, so I will keep MSE as the acronym", "computer science (CS)", "computer engineering (CE)" in my application form. Because materials engineering is not a very popular major, I got into MSE again. But soon after I stared my degree, I regretted it. Most courses in MSE need only memorisation, not  understanding and not reasoning. And I am particularly bad at memorisation. So I hated the courses and wanted to change my major to CS or CE. I had a lot of arguments with my mom and my uncle about switching my major. Both of them thought that MSE is a promising major, but too many people study in CS and CE, it will be difficult for me to find a job because I will not be able to distinguish myself among my peers. Even till now, I think they were completely wrong. Indeed there are more people studying in CS and CE than MSE, but there are also much more jobs available for CS, CE graduates than MSE! So at the end, MSE graduates are even more difficult to find jobs! But anyway, I didn't change my major, not because I didn't want to argue any more with my family, but because I loved one polymer course and thought maybe I could try MSE a bit longer than just one semester. After first year of my degree, I was really into 3D printing for a while. I did some research in 3D printing and later interned at a local 3D printing startup called Pirate3D. For sometime I wanted to quit research and join the gang of hackers and makers to start my own company. But for most of my life, I want to become a scientist, but I have never imagined becoming a "physicist". I did pretty well in physics in school. I could score full marks in physics every now and then. And I had the best score, 296 out of 300, in science (combination of physics, chemistry and biology) in my city for the National Entrance Exam (Gaokao, in pinyin). But I knew I wasn't good enough to become a physicist. Only geniuses can become physicists. In high school, I was also courageous enough to compare myself with Newton. I tried to invent Calculus at the age of 17. I believed Newton did the same at that age but obviously he did it much later. The age 17 probably came from the story of Gauss demonstrated heptadecagon (polygon with 17 edges) as a constructible polygon at the age of 19. (The 17 comes from the polygon rather than the age of Gauss at that time, :)) But I failed miserably. I didn't even know what calculus is! I just knew it's useful to calculate area under the curve. So becoming a physicist never came into my mind, until I attended the OCPA8 International Conference (OCPA stands for Overseas Chinese Physicists Association) in June 2014. I was quite frustrated in MSE research at that time. I thought all MSE research were labor intensive activity, were just mixing stuff and cooking them. (I still think so) I couldn't much intellectual pleasure in doing MSE research. Sometimes I even felt MSE research was not scientific because it needs a lot of luck to do well. (true for many engineering disciplines) But I met many smart and cool physicists in the OCPA8 conference. Some of them are in charge of large high energy facilities, like Daya Bay neutrino experiment (Wang Yifang), future high energy electron-electron collider with over 100km ring (Gao Jie), future fusion reactor tokamak (Ye Minyou, Wang Xiaogang), etc. Some of them have heart moving stories in their road to becoming physicists (Wu Lingan, W-Y. Pauchy Hwang). I was particularly motivated by Prof Pauchy Hwang. He lost his right leg in a car accident at the age of 10. But despite the tragedy, he tried to study well and became a professor in National Taiwan University. However, about 10 years later, another tragedy happened to him. He had a stroke attack, and since then he has to stay in a wheelchair and he can't speak properly any more. But he still keep working on his physics research. I thought compare to his difficulties, my fear for physics is just like a piece of cake. If I love physics, I should at least give it a try. So I did my final year project on molecular dynamic simulation of the photosynthetic reaction center of a bacteria. Although I didn't learn much about physics by doing this project per se, but I was exposed to some spin boson models in the weekly group meetings. Later I found a professor in Centre for Quantum Technology (CQT) in the National University of Singapore (NUS), and he agreed on taking me as a PhD student. However, my application was rejected, probably due to competitive selection and my poor physics background. So at the end, I found a temporary research assistant position at Energy Research Institute @ NTU (ERI@N), to do research on a recent hot topic: perovskite solar cells. At first I took this job as a temporary job just to feed myself, and meanwhile I studied more physics to prepare for next round of application. But after a while, I wanted to give up. Maybe physics is not for me and perovskite solar cell is a very promising topic that may bring me a lot of benefits. Indeed, I worked very hard and within a few months I got some interesting results to publish. The manuscript is almost ready for submission, and most of research work was done in October and November only! People in ERI@N start to appreciate my work and ability. Everything in my life is pointing to MSE again. But I don't feel secured. I don't feel happy. Somehow I feel this is not what I want. I did change my perspective on MSE research. Sometimes it can be fun and innovative. But most of the time is still cooking, and no reasoning, at least in ERI@N. I want more mental challenges and intellectual pleasures. I want to feel smart during and after PhD. About one month ago, I gave myself the last chance to try physics. I attended the School on Quantum Information Processing co-organised by the Institute of Advanced Studies in NTU and International Centre for Theoretical Physics. I got the same feeling I had in the OCPA8 conference. I felt very excited and anxious. I felt that everybody in the room is smarter than me, more capable than me, and I want to be as smart as they are. I felt everything they do is cool and interesting and I also want to work on the same thing. After the first week, I decided to apply for CQT again. I approached a professor in CQT, Prof Kwek, who I have also contacted one year ago. He knows me quite well and try to persuade me that ERI@N is a good place to be and energy is a good field to work on because Singapore government just announced a huge research plan in which hundreds of millions of dollars will go into sustainability research in the next 5 years. And if I want to switch to physics, computational materials might be easier for me, rather than quantum information. I think his advices are very reasonable, but I still want to go to CQT. So he suggest me to publish a paper before I apply again to demonstrate my knowledge and ability to do research in physics. Publish a paper in three months! from scratch! from a non-physics major student! It's like the challenge for the famous Mandopop singer Jay Chou to write 10 hit songs in a week to put in his first album. He did it and he became a superstar. But, can I do the same? Let's witness this. I'll keep posting my progress in this blog. Prof Kwek suggested me to study in quantum random walk. I found it also fit my journey to become a physicist, and hence it become the title for this post.

item.title: 1D Quantum Random Walk
item.dc:creator: hjunye
item.content:encoded:
Introduction Quantum random walk (QRW) is the quantum version of the classical random walk. It would be easier to understand the quantum version, if you get a picture of the classical version. Imagine you are walking in a narrow street, in which you can only walk forwards or backwards. You are playing this random walk game. You toss a coin: if it's head, you walk one step forwards; if it's tail, you walk one step backwards. If you keep tossing and walking, you are essentially doing a classical random walk (CRW) (in 1 dimension). It's that simple. If you calculate the probability of your position after N steps, you will get a Gaussian distribution. Galton board is probably a more familiar example of CRW than the game I just mentioned. You can see the Youtube video below. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6YDHBFVIvIs So what about the quantum version? What's so fancy about it? One peculiar thing in quantum mechanics (or Nature actually) is that you can have a superposition of two different state. So if  you (too massive to get superposition, just imagine you are a photon or electron) were to play the quantum version of random walking game, you can have a quantum coin which can have a superposition of head ($latex \left|\uparrow\right> $) and tail state($latex \left|\downarrow\right> $). Even more peculiar is that, you can have superposition of yourself at different locations! So if you measure the probability of your position after N steps, you will not get a Gaussian distribution, but a strange bimodal distribution. Unlike CRW where the most probable position is at the origin (the center), the most probable position in QRW is close to the two end (but not quite to the farthest possible position yet, about 0.7N-2 when 20<N<500). Some other peculiar properties for QRW includes:
  1. The probability distribution depends on your initial coin state,  $latex \left|\uparrow\right> $, $latex \left|\downarrow\right> $ or their superposition $latex \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\left|\uparrow\right>+\left|\downarrow\right>)$.
  2.  The probability distribution depends on the coin-flip operator (we will see below)
  3. QRW spreads $latex \sqrt{N}$ faster than CRW.

item.title: Historic Moment: AlphaGo vs Lee Sedol
item.dc:creator: hjunye
item.content:encoded: This week has been really exciting for me. I can't believe that I can see a live match between human and computer for Go, very much like the historic chess match between Kasparov and IBM Deep Blue in 1997. (I didn't watch this game; I was still in kindergarten) I just had a quick look at Deep Blue's wiki. AlphaGo is actually much more powerful in Go than Deep Blue was in chess. First, human intervention was needed for Deep Blue to modify the program between the games, to shore up the weaknesses revealed during the games. In the case of AlphaGo, Google claimed that the program remains the same throughout the match. Second, Deep Blue lost the first match (of 6 games) against Kasparov in 1996. It needed heavy upgrade to beat Kasparov with a margin: 3½:2½ in 1997, while for AlphaGo, it didn't give Lee Sedol a single chance to win so far (3:0 right now, the fourth game is ongoing at this moment) (Update: Lee Sedol just won the fourth game! So now the score is 3:1!) Deep Blue's strategy is "brute force". It uses strong computation power to calculate all the possible positions in many steps ahead. (It can evaluate 200 millions positions per second according to Wikipedia) In June 1997, Deep Blue was the 259th most powerful supercomputer according to the TOP500 list, with 11.38 GFLOPs computation power. (I was checking how powerful is 11.38GFLOPS, and found out that it's only at the same level of iPhone 4s's CPU) Of course, almost 20 years later, AlphaGo uses much more powerful hardware than Deep Blue. It uses 1920 CPUs and 280 GPUs, that means it has computation power above 100TFLOPS. (assuming 50GFLPS per CPU). The 500th on TOP500 list in Nov 2015 has about 200TFLOPS computation power, so AlphaGo's hardware can probably be listed on TOP500 too. However, because of the complexity of Go, even with a 10000 times more powerful hardware, AlphaGo can't use "brute force" approach. According to the Nature paper published by Google, AlphaGo combines Monte Carlo tree search algorithm with a policy network and a value network to play the game. The value network evaluate the positions, and the policy network selects the move. (I haven't read through the Nature paper yet, so I can't really explain how it works) By combining these two networks, AlphaGo can limit the number of searches to a few positions on the board and a few tens of steps ahead. Before writing this post, I was really amazed by the ability of AlphaGo to win against the strongest human Go player. But after knowing that this program needed so much work and innovations in the software and so much power on the hardware, I started to appreciate the power of human brain. There are still a lot of jobs that machine can't do, fortunately or unfortunately. But the future is clear: we will have much more powerful AI in our daily life. Our human need to co-evolve with them. Maybe one day in the future, we don't need to learn anything. Every single technical and professional job will be done by computer. Our job is to enjoy our life. But will we enjoy our life if we don't need to work? Will AI take over our world like Ghost in the Shell and Ultron from Avengers? Elon Musk CEO of Tesla Motor and SpaceX) and Sam Altman (President of Y combinator) created a billion dollar not-for-profit organization called OpenAI to prevent some companies or countries using AI to take over the world. That actually doesn't prevent AI itself from taking over the world though. Anyway, this series of game has generated a lot of attentions to AI and machine learning. It will inspire a lot of young people to learn AI and ML. It might also have attached the attentions of policy makers and funding agencies. Like someone said, AI has been pushed forward for 10 years in the last few days. There is one more game to enjoy on Tuesday. (in fact I can't really "enjoy" the game by watching it because I barely knows the rules of Go and played a few times in my life) Hope Lee Sedol can win one more time.

item.title: PhD application
item.dc:creator: hjunye
item.content:encoded: I didn't write a post in April, and June is around the corner. I can't procrastinate any more. I think I just put too much pressure for myself to write only "perfect" blogposts that at the end I am too afraid to start writing. I should just take it easy. Anyway, no one will give a shit for what I am writing here. In fact, there won't be anyone reading this post probably. As mentioned in a previous post, I wanted to become a theoretical physicist and I was struggling to get admitted to graduate school. I found a professor, Prof Kwek, who is kind enough to take me as a PhD student, but he is not very optimistic about the application. So he suggested me to work on a project and write a paper before I submit the application. I started to work on quantum random walk suggested by Prof Kwek. After a while, I felt I wasn't ready for a theoretical physics PhD. This thought wasn't induced by the difficulties of the quantum random walk project though; I am having great progress on it. But after thinking about my PhD for many many times, I realised my physics foundation is too weak. It will take me minimal one year of full time efforts to learn quantum mechanics, statistical mechanics and electrodynamics, which are absolutely essential for a PhD on quantum information. Furthermore, this estimation of one year efforts is over optimistic. I barely use mathematics for my undergraduate. It will take me sometime to get comfortable and confident of using mathematics. With these thoughts, I decided to look for a research assistant position in a physics lab so that I can catch up with physics while working. However, finding a RA position in a physics lab is no easier than finding a PhD in a physics lab. I tried to contact a few professors but the results were all negative. Who will prefer to hire someone with little research experience in physics and come from non-physics background to do physics research? Meanwhile, my girlfriend just got a confirmation of PhD scholarship. I suddenly felt impatient and hopeless. Maybe I shouldn't try to walk the tougher way. Why don't I just stick with materials science? Maybe physics is really not my thing. I was desperate. Finally I sent out an email to a professor who I have been following for a while. His main research interest is spintronics on graphene. Since it's at least related to materials, I thought I might have a chance to do PhD under him. I got his reply only seconds after I sent my email. To my surprise, he not only wants me to do PhD under him, but also to work at the same time as a research assistant to manage the lab. It's a perfect match for me! I can clear my 6 year bond from undergraduate scholarship and do a PhD in physics, although not theoretical physics that I intended to do initially. The name of this professor is Barbaros Özyilmaz. He is a German, probably with Turkish ancestry deduced from his surname. He is in his early 40s, but he is already a full professor in not just one, but two departments in NUS: Department of Physics and Department of Materials Science and Engineering. He obtained his PhD on spintronics in New York University in 2004 and then he went to Philip Kim's lab in Columbia University in 2005 to work on the newly discovered graphene. He was involved in two highly cited (>3500 citations) : Roll-to-roll production of 30-inch graphene films for transparent electrodes, and Energy band-gap engineering of graphene nanoribbons. He is an expert in spintronics, especially in graphene-based spintronics. If everything goes smoothly, I will work on spintronics application based on another 2D material. Things cannot be more perfect. There is only one catch: I need to become a permanent resident of Singapore. His funding can only hire Singaporeans or Singapore PRs. Luckily, I already applied for it two months ago, and I should get the approval at latest in September. It is usually easy to get approval for people like me who have studied undergraduate in Singapore with a scholarship. But I don't like the feeling of "all my future is depending on this and I can do nothing about it". I just hope everything will go well and finally I can start working on physics research. If my PR application gets rejected, I will take it as destiny. I will be really fed up with this PhD thing, and choose to do a startup.

item.title: Elon Musk
item.dc:creator: hjunye
item.content:encoded: Recently, I have read a biography and a few excellent blogposts on wait but why about Elon Musk. For those who don't know about Elon Musk, he is the most crazy entrepreneur in the world. He was a co-founder of a few Internet companies, including PayPal. He is currently running at the same time two of the most incredible startups in the world: SpaceX and Tesla Motor. SpaceX is awesome. It was founded by Elon at 2002, aiming to colonise Mars to make us, homo sapiens sapiens, a multi-planetary species. Through many years of struggles, SpaceX has designed its rocket engines and many other parts from ground up, making its rockets the cheapest yet one of the most powerful ones in history. Its rockets can be launched and return to the designate areas with accuracy of a few meters like science fiction. It has plans to send unmanned spacecrafts to Mars at 2018 and eventually send people to Mars as early as 2025. To be fair, compare to SpaceX, Tesla Motor is a bit less exciting, but that doesn't prevent Tesla to revolutionise our life. Tesla is not the first company to produce electric vehicles. In fact, electric cars exist as long as internal combustion engine cars. The core innovation of Tesla's cars is the use of lithium ion batteries. With high energy density Li ion batteries and great batteries management software, Tesla's Model S outperform any luxury cars on the market with 4.2s acceleration from 0 to 60 mph while keeping a long driving range of 300 miles. Next year, Tesla is going to release the more affordable Model 3 with acceleration from 0 to 60 mph under 6s and 215 miles range at around 35,000 USD. Right now, there's less than 200,000 Tesla cars (Model S + Model X) on the road. But as of May 2016, the reservation of Model 3 already reached 373,000 and Tesla has plans to produce over a million Model 3. Though still a small number compare to worldwide annual production of  close to 100 millions cars, together with the competition Tesla has attracted (Nissan Leaf, BMW i3, etc), Model 3 is going to lead a electric vehicle revolution in the coming years. One of the most striking characteristic of Elon Musk, as pointed out by Tim Urban on his Wait But Why posts, is his ability to think on first principle. He reasoned that because the raw materials cost of a rocket is merely 2% of its currently cost, there must be ways to cut down the cost of a rocket significantly through innovation. He deeply believes in this conclusion and use his leadership power to drive his employees to innovate. The result, SpaceX created the most efficient rocket engine in history, it cut down costs of numerous components by using consumer grade electronics component which were proven to be reliable enough for space travel, and most important of all, SpaceX is inventing a way to cut down rocket launch cost by reusing its rockets. For Tesla, as I said, it's not the first electric car in the world. Its key innovation is in the batteries. It replaced traditional lead acid or nickel hydrogen battery with higher energy density Li ion batteries.

item.title: Writing a blogpost
item.dc:creator: hjunye
item.content:encoded: Every time I want to write a blogpost, I will have tremendous pressure. I don't want to write something that make others think I am stupid. I want to write something that is logical and thoughtful like Wait But Why. But then, with all these things in my head, I will never really write a post. So, I decided, from now on, I will just write whatever that is in my head. No one will give a shit to what I write. In fact, no one reads my blog at all. So fuck it. This blog should be my little playground, my own kingdom. Just treat it as a notebook, a diary. I just want to write as freely as I felt in my first blog on Baidu when I was in secondary school and high school.

item.title: Next step
item.dc:creator: hjunye
item.content:encoded: I mentioned in a earlier post that I will go to NUS to do my PhD. The PhD application is still processing, but I will start working in Prof  Özyilmaz's lab from 15 Aug. I will be working on the study of spin transport properties of phosphorene, monolayer of black phosphorous. Phosphorene was first discovered in 2013 by a group of physicists in China. The lead scientist is called Zhang Yuanbo, who was among the first researcher to work on graphene in 2004 while he was doing PhD in Philip Kim's group. Zhang Yuanbo became a professor in Fudan University in Shanghai in 2009. He is one of the most renown young scientists in 2D materials. I hope I will be as good as he is. Prof Özyilmaz's group was also among the first to report about phosphorene and its electric field effect. That paper has been already cited over 300 times, only after 2 years of its publication. Phosphorene is now the hottest 2D material, due to its low band gap (tunable from 0.3 to 2 eV) and high mobility (up to 1000 cm2⋅V−1⋅s−1). It can be used in energy storage, photovoltaics, thermoelectrics and of course nanoelectronics. The main research activity in Prof Özyilmaz's group is graphene spintronics. Given the rise of phosphorene, it is natural to expand the graphene spintronics activity to phosphorene spintronics. In fact, Prof Özyilmaz told me they already obtained great results and submitted the manuscript to a Nature series journal (Nature Physics or Nature Nanotechnology) So it is already proven that phosphorene is a proven great material for spintronics, and my PhD is guarantee to be a success as long as I make my full efforts into it. I'll be thrilled to be able to work on cutting-edge research and publish in Nature or Science journals. It seems I am so close to tip of ivory tower of research! Ideally, if everything works well, I will be able to publish a few great papers by the end of my PhD. And I will be good to go to TOP10 universities to do postdoc. It is definitely too early to think about it. But me being me, I already thought of a potential supervisor for my postdoc: Pablo Jarillo-Herrero at MIT. I am sure you will be amazed by his list of publications. Out of only 60 papers he published, 25 (21 in the last 6 years) papers are on Nature/Science (excluding Nature Communications)! His main research focus is quantum transport study in 2D materials, which is closely related to what I will do. In fact, Prof Özyilmaz has collaboration with him. They both did postdoc in Philip Kim's group. I can't believe MIT is so close to me. In the summer of my freshmen year, I went to visit MIT (just for tourism). I spent two days just wondering around MIT campus. Have you ever had an experience of feeling like in the heaven, feeling satisfied just by the fact that you are there? It's like a Muslim finally reach Mecca. That's how I felt. At that time, I was so convinced that I would do my PhD in MIT. I found a corner near the famous dome of MIT and wrote "I'll be back" using a rock. I'll be so satisfied if I can finally do research to MIT, even just for one or two years as postdoc. I really can't wait to start working in NUS.

item.title: University Rankings
item.dc:creator: hjunye
item.content:encoded:
NTU loves rankings. If you go to its official website, you can see most of its news highlights are about rankings: "NTU is the 3rd in Asia and 1st in research citations" "Top in Singapore, 32nd globally. 5th in Chemistry, 27th in Physical Sciences in Nature Index 2016" "No.2 among the world's young universities. NTU." "Singapore's no. 1 MBA programme. NTU jumps 11 places to 29th globally." "NTU is ranked No.1 for the 2nd consecutive year in QS young universities world ranking" "NTU jumps 114 places in 4 years" "NTU charges ahead to no.13 globally" It's a bit too much, isn't it? When I started my undergraduate study in 2011, NTU was only ranked 169th in Times Higher Education ranking. Now, it's 55th. In QS ranking, which in general ranks NTU much higher than THE ranking, NTU now is 13th in the world, just one place behind its old brother NUS. The subject ranking is even more exaggerating, especially for materials science. QS ranks NTU at 6th, and US News ranks NTU at 2nd, surpassing all the world class universities, like Stanford, UC Berkeley, and Cambridge, only behind MIT. As a alumnus of School of Materials Science and Engineering at NTU, I am of course more than thrilled to know that our school (actually the subject ranking ranks all the materials science related papers published across all the schools in NTU, rather than only MSE) is on par with the world's best. But I clearly know that these rankings can't give the whole picture. There is no doubt that NTU publishes high impact papers, and in a huge amount, which is basically what the methodologies of these rankings are based on. But most of NTU research are just good, not excellent. We have a lot of Advanced Materials, JACS, EES, ACS nano, nanoscale papers, but seldom publish Nature/Science papers. There is not much scientific breakthroughs here. For this fact, I don't think we are on par with Stanford, UC Berkeley and Cambridge. Nevertheless, despite the inevitable flaws in any rankings, these rankings by different entities clearly show that NTU is on the rise. Like our president Bertil Anderson said in the email in response to the QS ranking last year where NTU was ranked at 13th:
I know some of us may scoff at rankings, but I will argue that while it may be an imperfect and blunt measurement of the quality of universities, it is useful to young universities like NTU. It allows up-and-coming universities like us to benchmark with the best in the world and visualise our progress. In the old days before rankings, legacy and reputation perceptions mattered most. Isn’t that even more imperfect, to have perceptions passed down through the centuries about which universities are doing good work? It would be difficult for young universities to compete against the established ones without a more objective system for measuring progress. With the common yardsticks today, young universities can show how they are raising the ante in competition with the older, established universities.
With these rankings, NTU can confidently advertise itself, attract better students, better faculty, and in turn push its research level to a new height. At the very least, next time someone ask me about where I studied, I can proudly say that I studied in one of the world's best universities and one of the best schools. :)

item.title: A low cost braille typewriter
item.dc:creator: hjunye
item.content:encoded:
This blogpost is inspired by Aaron Swartz, the Internet's own boy. For his short lifetime (26 years) on this planet, he had made so many technological and social contributions to the society, including RSS, Creative Commons, Markdown, and Open Access movement. I am going to be 24 years old in October this year, and yet I am practically nobody. Nobody, except some friends and family, will remember me if I die today. I have studied in schools for almost 20 years. I should have learnt enough knowledge and gained the ability to create some impacts to the society. Yes, I am going to start my PhD soon. And yes, if it goes well, it might be important. But I want to do something closer to normal people, not just some fancy 2D heterostructure devices. There is something I has really wanted to do for a while: a low cost braille typewriter/brailler. I went to teach in a primary school in Kenya 3 years ago during my summer break. That school has visually impaired students and the school is famous enough to have charity organization to donate braillers. However, there is still not enough braillers for every visually impaired student, because of a fucking Perskin brailler costs more than $700! A machine based on 20th century technology costs more than the most advanced smartphone in the world! This is absolutely insane! There got to be a way to cut down the cost. Here are my brief ideas:
  1. Replace complicated mechanical design by electronic circuits.
  2. Use 3D printers to print most of the parts to avoid huge fixed costs in traditional manufacturing methods.
  3. Find a way to type on cheap and easy-to-find normal paper instead of expensive braille paper.
I am not sure about the reasons of the high cost. I assume it's because of the complicated mechanical design and huge fixed costs that cannot be reduced by economy-of-scale due to the small market. I need to verify all these assumptions before moving forward. A new mechanical design might be even cheaper and more reliable and no need power source. I have found a paper from 2001 by an Australian research group about an electronic design of brailler. It would be a good start point to make a brailler based on this design. One possible problem for electronic design is the need of power source, which could be a problem in extremely undeveloped regions. A combination of hand crank generator with a battery or supercapacitor is a possible solution. For the 3rd idea, I am not so sure about the problem. I have tried to use a pen to indent on a normal paper, and the indentation seems easy to touch (read) and rigid (won't be flatten easily). This brailler should look pretty much the same as a traditional brailler. The idea is to cut down the cost only, not to create a revolutionary next-generation brailler. There are many new innovations in braille industry, including braille display, braille ebook. But they are all extremely expensive and quite useless. For visually impaired people in rich countries, there are many ways for them to obtain information, radio, TV, audiobooks... Braille is quite useless. However, for those who lives in poor countries, braille might their only way of getting information. An affordable brailler will make much bigger impacts in these countries. More people can afford to buy one, schools can buy more braillers for students. These all sound great and reasonable, aren't they? Why isn't there already a cheap brailler on the market? The reason is exactly because no one in rich country cares about brailler any more. No one is going to buy a brailler and no market means no innovation. I haven't really started to work on it because I thought I can't make it and I didn't have time to make it until today i realised these are all excuses. I am going to start doing this thing from today. It will be my side project during PhD. I will devote my spare time to work on it. And I will make it open source. And if I really make it I will try to contact some organisations to support me for manufacturing or launch kickstarter campaign. It shouldn't just lie on my bedroom or on the Internet. It must create real impacts in the world.

item.title: NLI Series: Chen-Ning Yang
item.dc:creator: hjunye
item.content:encoded: This is the first post of the Nobel Laureates Impressions series. Please check here to find out more posts in the series. When I decided to write this series, I didn't think for a second to put Chen-Ning Yang in the first post for a few reasons. First, he probably got the Nobel prize (in 1957) earlier than anyone alive (except, of course, Tsung-Dao Lee, who shared the Nobel prize with CN Yang). Indeed, he was among the youngest to got the prize (at 35, only 16 laureates were younger at the time of award) and he is 93 years old already. Second, he was the first Chinese Nobel laureate (again, same for Tsung-Dao Lee). Third, CN Yang has made the biggest contributions to physics among all Chinese. He is considered the "best" Chinese physicist of all time. Of course, the last reason is that I have met him in person, but not Tsung-Dao Lee, which is the criteria of this post series. NTU has a CN Yang Scholarship program, named in honour of CN Yang. Among other benefits, CN Yang scholars have the opportunity to interact with CN Yang privately when he visits Singapore. It is because of this scholarship program, CN Yang comes once every one to two years to Singapore. I have long been a fan of CN Yang. Since primary school, I got to know that he is the first Chinese to be awarded Nobel prize. But not until I read his biography, did I realise how important he is to modern physics. There is a good summary of his works (13 problems in 4 fields) by Fudan University professor Shi Yu, published on a Chinese journal Physics. I quote it here: (A) Statistical Mechanics A1. 1952 Phase Transition A2. 1957 Bosons A3. 1967 Yang—Baxter Equation A4. 1969 Finite Temperature (B) Condensed Matter Physics B1. 1961 Flux Quantization B2. 1962 ODLRO (C) Particle Physics C1. 1956 Parity Nonconservation C2. 1957 T, C and P C3. 1960 Neutrino Experiment C4. 1964 CP Nonconservation (D) Field Theory D1. 1954 Gauge Theory D2. 1974 Integral Formalism D3. 1975 Fibre Bundle The contributions were also engraved in the black marble cube given to CN Yang by Tsinghua University in his 90th birthday. However, despite the fact that he is one of the most important physicist alive, most Chinese got to know him because of his young wife, not because of his contributions to physics. If you search Yang's name in Chinese, the top results are almost exclusively about his wife. 老牛吃嫩草 (lao niu chi nen cao, old cow eats young grass) is the world they use to describe Yang's second marriage.  They can't believe that a young and beautiful girl can fall in love with an old man more than 80 years old. "She loves the fame and money of Yang only, not Yang himself." they think. Many Chinese also complained that Yang didn't come back to "serve" the country when the country needed him the most and only came back after 2000 when China already became one of the strongest economy in the world. There are also numerous articles talking about this. Yang is often compared with Qian Xuesen, who came back to China to develop rocket and missiles after becoming a professor in the US, and Deng Jiaxian, who was a childhood friend of Yang and also went to US to study and later came back to China to develop China's first atomic bomb. "Science has no boundaries, but scientists have nationality" (科学无国界，可是科学家有国籍) is topic that worth to write a post itself. I am not trying to argue about it here. Let's come back to the meat of the post: my personal impression of CN Yang. I met him at OCPA8 conference in 2014 which changed my research direction to physics.
